The goal of LGST218 is to study the role the law has played, and continues to play, in addressing the problems of racial discrimination in the United States. Contemporary issues such as racial profiling, affirmative action, and diversity will all be covered in their social and legal context. The basis for discussion will be assigned texts, articles, editorials and cases. In addition, interactive videos will also be used to aid class discussion. Course requirements will include examinations and class discussions.

Students overall felt the class was “easy and understandable,” with a fair amount of emphasis on the readings and valuable learning experience.

Most students described Anderson as “interesting and hilarious,” though some characterized the humor in the class to be “dry” at times. Some felt the lectures were “a little too messy,” but most found Anderson capable of conveying the subject matter and being able to meet outside of class.

This course requires some readings which are used in lectures. The course comes fairly recommended to both majors and non-majors.
